t: Job 30
But*pn now they mock me, men*ln younger than I am, whose*ln fathers I would have refused to put with*ln my sheep dogs.
What*ln use to me was the strength of their hands? Their*ln vigor had left them.
Emaciated*ln from poverty and hunger, they*ln gnawed the dry land, the*ln desolate wasteland by night.
They*ln plucked mallow among the shrubs, and*ln the roots of the broom tree were their food.
They*ln were banished from human society; people*ln shouted at them as if they were thieves.
They*ln are living on the slopes of the wadis, among*ln the rocks and in holes in the ground.
They*ln bray among the shrubs; they*ln huddle beneath the thistles.
Foolish*ln men, without even a name. They*ln were forced to leave the land.
Now*pn I am mocked by their songs; I*ln have become an object of scorn to them.
They*ln despise me and keep their distance from me; they*ln do not hesitate to spit in my face.
Because*ln God has loosened my bowstring and oppressed me, they*ln have cast off restraint in my presence.
The*ln rabble rise up at my right; they*ln trap my feet and*ln construct their siege ramp against me.
They*ln tear up my path; they*ln contribute to my destruction, without*ln anyone to help them.
They*ln advance as through a gaping breach; they*ln keep rolling in through the ruins.
Terrors*ln are turned loose against me; they*ln chase my dignity away like the wind, and*ln my prosperity has passed by like a cloud.
Now*pn my life is poured out before me, and*ln days of suffering have seized me.
Night*ln pierces my bones, but*ln my gnawing pains never rest.
My*ln clothing is distorted with great force; he*ln chokes me by the neck of my garment.
He*ln throws me into the mud, and*ln I have become like dust and ashes.
I*pn cry out to you for help, but you do not answer me; when*ln I stand up, you merely look at me.
You*ln have turned against me with cruelty; you*ln harass me with your strong hand.
You*ln lift me up on the wind and make me ride it; you*ln scatter me in the storm.
Yes,*ln I know that you will lead me to death — the*ln place appointed for all who live.
Yet*pn no one would stretch out his hand against*ln a ruined person when*ln he cries out to him for help because*ln of his distress.
Have*ln I not wept for those who have fallen on hard times? Has*ln my soul not grieved for the needy?
But*ln when I hoped for good, evil came; when*ln I looked for light, darkness came.
I*ln am churning within and cannot rest; days*ln of suffering confront me.
I*ln walk about blackened, but not by the sun. I*ln stood in the assembly and cried out for help.
I*ln have become a brother to jackals and*ln a companion of ostriches.
My*ln skin blackens and flakes off, and*ln my bones burn with fever.
My*ln lyre is used for mourning and*ln my flute for the sound of weeping.
